title: 4. Suicidality
content:
Everyone who talks about low mood, or who is suspected of having low mood, should be
asked if they are thinking about hurting themselves.
Risk for suicide
Risk factors for suicide are varied/no single cause or stressor alone can explain a suicidal act.
Although the scale scoring may not be valid in Ethiopia, in other countries, having six or more of the factors on “SAD PERSONS” Scale indicates substantial risk.
• Sex (available data in Ethiopia do not find that the rate of attempts is that different between men and women; in other countries being male puts one at more risk)
• Age (attempts in Ethiopia seem more common among older teens and young adults)

title: Suicide Risk Screening
content:
Over the past few weeks, how often have you been bothered by any of the following problems?
In the past few weeks, have you felt that you or your family would be better off if you were dead?
In the past week, have you been having thoughts about killing yourself?
Have you ever tried to kill yourself?
If the patient answers yes to any of the above, ask the following question: Are you having thoughts of killing yourself right now?
If the answer to any of these questions is “yes” then the risk of suicide should be high, consider the following:
Patients require a STAT safety/full mental health evaluation.
Patients cannot leave until they are evaluated for safety.
Keep patient in sight.
Remove all dangerous objects from the room.
Alert physician or clinician responsible for patient’s care.
5.Positive Mental Health/well-being Techniques
Promoting positive mental health or improving mental health and well-being involves a combination of lifestyle changes, coping strategies, and professional support. Well-being strategies in mental health focus on maintaining emotional, psychological, and social well-being. Promoting positive mental health involves maintaining emotional resilience, fostering supportive relationships, and engaging in activities that enhance well-being.
